skill.name: medchem
skill.description: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural alerts, complexity metrics, for compound prioritization and library filtering.
skill.summary: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural ...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation and Python script for molecular filtering. No network calls, no credential access, no persistence mechanisms. All file I/O is for legitimate chemical data processing (CSV, SDF, TXT). Code behavior matches stated purpose of medicinal chemistry library.

content.value_statement: Screening large compound libraries for drug candidates is time-consuming. This skill applies established medicinal chemistry rules like Lipinski Rule of Five, PAINS filters, and structural alerts to automatically identify promising compounds for further study.
actual_capabilities: Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber, CNS, leadlike) to molecule libraries
Detect structural alerts and PAINS patterns that indicate problematic compounds
Calculate molecular complexity metrics for synthetic accessibility assessment
Run batch filtering workflows on CSV, SDF, or SMILES input files
Identify specific chemical groups like hinge binders and Michael acceptors
limitations: Requires installation of medchem, datamol, pandas, and RDKit dependencies
Filters are guidelines, not absolute rules—false positives and negatives occur
Does not predict biological activity or binding affinity

use_cases.title: Prioritize virtual screening hits
use_cases.description: Filter large virtual libraries to identify drug-like candidates before experimental testing.

use_cases.title: Support lead optimization
use_cases.description: Apply stricter criteria during lead optimization to improve compound developability.

use_cases.title: Quality control for libraries
use_cases.description: Remove compounds with reactive groups or known assay interference patterns from screening collections.

prompt_templates.title: Quick rule check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if this SMILES [SMILES_STRING] passes the Rule of Five and has no PAINS alerts using medchem.

prompt_templates.title: Library filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter this list of molecules for drug-likeness. Apply rule of five, rule of cns, and flag any with common structural alerts.

prompt_templates.title: Lead optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply leadlike strict criteria and Lilly demerits filter to these compounds. Report which ones pass all filters.

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a comprehensive medchem analysis on this compound library: apply all relevant rules, check structural alerts, calculate complexity, and generate a summary report.

output_examples.input: Check if these SMILES pass drug-likeness rules: CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O, c1ccccc1
output: Aspirin (CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O): PASSES Rule of Five, PASSES Veber rules, no PAINS detected
Benzene (c1ccccc1): FAILS Rule of Five (MW < 200), no alerts but poor drug candidate

best_practices: Use parallelization (n_jobs=-1) for large libraries to speed up filtering
Combine multiple filters (rules + structural alerts) for comprehensive quality control
Document which compounds were filtered and why for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Blindly accepting all filter results without domain knowledge review
Applying the same filters to all target classes without adjustment
Ignoring that marketed drugs often violate standard rules

faq.question: Does medchem work with all molecule formats?
faq.answer: It supports SMILES strings, SDF files, and CSV with SMILES columns through the datamol library.

faq.question: What are the computational limits for large libraries?
faq.answer: Processing time scales with molecule count. Use n_jobs=-1 for parallel processing on multi-core systems.

faq.question: Can medchem integrate with other cheminformatics tools?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with RDKit molecule objects and pandas DataFrames for downstream analysis.

faq.question: Is my chemical data stored or transmitted anywhere?
faq.answer: No, medchem runs locally. No data leaves your machine during filtering operations.

faq.question: Why do some known drugs fail the filters?
faq.answer: Rules are guidelines, not absolutes. Many drugs violate Rule of Five, especially natural products and antibiotics.

faq.question: How does medchem compare to other filtering tools?
faq.answer: Medchem combines multiple rule sets (Lipinski, Veber, NIBR, Lilly) in one library with parallel processing support.
